slides.title: Detail Views
slides.ocrText: Detail Views

slides.title: Learning Objectives
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Describe the functionality of Detail Views

* Create a new Detail View

• Reference a Detail View from a parent
container

• Describe how to make a Detail View editable

• Create a Toolbar with Edit Buttons

• Understand Dashboards and their use

slides.title: About Detail Views
slides.ocrText: About Detail Views

slides.title: Review: Detail View
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Detail View
Detail view panels are generally designed to use widgets to organize and manage a collection of related pieces of information that constitute a single record. The most obvious example is the set of individual fields of an instance of an entity such as User, Claim, or Policy. There are no constraints imposed by the system as to what information can be displayed by a detail view, however; the view could present information from multiple entities that do not even have to be related to one another, in addition to information that does not derive from an entity at all (such as calculated or static values).

The purpose of a detail view panel, however, and the recommended practice behind their use, is to present the user with all of the detailed information that is relevant to that interface, and no information that is irrelevant. In general, this means displaying information about the fields of a particular entity and possibly fields from a small number of closely related entities.

Detail view panels must contain at least one column and can contain as many columns as necessary to present the widgets in the most effective way for the user.
slides.notes:

Example (3 of 4)
Next, we add the Detail View Panel. The Detail View Panel must have at least one Input Column. The Input Column will contain the atomic widgets and
display them using a vertical layout. Technically, you can think about the Detail View as an Input Column container. It must contain one to define the vertical layout..

slides.title: Inline widget vs. PCF file
slides.originalNotes:
Inline widget vs. PCF file
When a container such as a detail view panel is a top-level container, it is reusable. A top- level container is a PCF file. Ifthe container is likely to be needed in multiple places, create a PCF file for the container. A Detail View Panel is PCF file that is ideal for multiple references. Other PCF files can reference the reusable container using a reference widget. In TrainingApp, the ABContactSummaryPage contains a Screen with a Panel Ref that references ABContactSummaryDV. Panel Ref widgets are discussed later in this lesson.

When a container such as detail view panel is declared as an inline child container, it is not reusable. Other containers cannot reference an inline container A Detail View widget is defined in a Screen, Card, or a List Detail Panel. It is possible to define a variable for a Detail View widget object, but this is uncommon. A Detail View widget inherits the root object associated with its parent.
slides.notes:

Other PCF files can reference the reusable container using a reference widget. In TrainingApp, the ABContactSummaryPage contains a Screen with a Panel Ref that references ABContactSummaryDV. Panel Ref widgets are discussed later in this lesson.

When a container such as detail view panel is declared as an inline child container, it is not reusable. It is possible to define a variable for a Detail View widget object, but this is uncommon. A Detail View widget inherits the root object associated with its parent.

View.

First, we create the ABContactSummaryScreen.pcf and define a new root object anABContact : ABContact. (Remember, the root object is the input parameter of the container)

slides.title: Inline widget vs. PCF file example (4 of 8)
slides.originalNotes:
Inline widget vs. PCF file example (4 of 8)
And finally, we add the Input Column and the atomic widgets. Notice that everything is yellow because they are defined in the same PCF file. In this example, only the Screen is reusable, everything else is inline. Also notice there is only one root object and all the inline containers have direct access (they "inherit") to that root object.

slides.title: Toolbars
slides.originalNotes:
Toolbars
A toolbar is a row of widgets associated with a container widget that lets the user take action on the data in the container widget.

A toolbar can be directly added to a Screen, Panel Ref, or List View Input. Toolbars can also be associated with Detail View Panels, Card View Panels, List Detail Panels, and List View Panels. However, there is no direct placement or reference with an Input Set- Typically, an Input Set is referenced or placed in an Input Column in a Detail View Panel.

A toolbar usually has button widgets such as Edit Buttons. When a toolbar is associated with a list view panel, the toolbar may not have any button widgets. This is configuration is covered later in the course.
slides.notes:
Toolbars
A toolbar is a row of widgets associated with a container widget that lets the user take action on the data in the container widget.

A toolbar can be directly added to a Screen, Panel Ref, or List View Input. Toolbars can also be associated with Detail View Panels, Card View Panels, List Detail Panels, and List View Panels. However, there is no direct placement or reference with an Input Set- Typically, an Input Set is referenced or placed in an Input Column in a Detail View Panel.

A toolbar usually has button widgets such as Edit Buttons. When a toolbar is associated with a list view panel, the toolbar may not have any button widgets. This is configuration is covered later in the course.
slides.ocrText:
| Toolbars G

• A toolbar is a horizontal bar containing buttons and other useful widgets. It can be
used at the top of a Screen or before including a Panel.

• Usually has Edit Buttons

slides.title: Edit buttons
slides.originalNotes:
Edit buttons
When a user clicks Edit, the input widgets switch from read-only to edit mode. In addition, an entry is made in the unsaved work menu for the data backed object (entity) on the screen.

When a user clicks Update, the Guidewire application commits the changes to the data backed object on the screen; the input widgets switch from edit mode to read-only mode; and the entry in the unsaved work menu for the data backed object (entity) on the screen is removed.

When a user clicks Cancel, the Guidewire application does not commit the changes to the data backed object on the screen; the input widgets switch from edit mode to read-only mode; and the entry in the unsaved work menu for the data backed object (entity) on the screen is removed.
slides.notes:
Edit buttons

When a user clicks Cancel, the Guidewire application does not commit the changes to the data backed object on the screen; the input widgets switch from edit mode to read-only mode; and the entry in the unsaved work menu for the data backed object (entity) on the screen is removed.

slides.ocrText:
| Social Media (Part C) G

In the previous demo, we implemented The Social Media tab for an insurance
company. After reviewing the configured screen, the business analysts were pleased
with the results and they just submitted a new related feature request: they want to
see the exact same screen layout when they navigate to the Social Media link in the

sidebar.

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
A Detail View that displays data must have at least one root object. Why?
•
•
sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo

questionData.question: A Detail View that displays data must have at least one root object. Why?
questionData.answer: The input widgets of a Detail View must reference some object in order to specify where the data they display comes from. This object must be the root object, or an object related to the root object. Therefore, in order to display data, a root object is needed. sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
A Detail View that displays data must have at least one root object. Why?
•
•
•
The input widgets of a Detail View must reference some object in order to specify
where the data they display comes from. This object must be the root object, or an
object related to the root object. Therefore, in order to display data, a root object is
needed.
sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

slides.title: Question
slides.ocrText:
Question G
A Detail View that displays data must have at least one input column.
• Why?
•
•
sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo

questionData.question: A Detail View that displays data must have at least one input column.
questionData.answer: SSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe A Detail View that displays data must have at least one input column. Input columns are used to organize atomic widgets in a Detail View. Every input widget must be in an input column. If a Detail View displays data, then it has at least one input widget, which means it must have at least one input column.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
•
•
•
sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe
A Detail View that displays data must have at least one input column.
Why?
Input columns are used to organize atomic widgets in a Detail View. Every input
widget must be in an input column. If a Detail View displays data, then it has at least
one input widget, which means it must have at least one input column.
Gi

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What determines if a detail view panel is reusable or not?
•
•
sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo

questionData.question: What determines if a detail view panel is reusable or not?
questionData.answer: SSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe If a Detail View is declared as the parent object of a PCF file, then it is reusable. It can be referenced by any number of other containers.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
•
•
•
sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe
What determines if a Detail View is reusable or not?
If a Detail View is declared as the parent object of a PCF file, then it is reusable. It can
be referenced by any number of other containers.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
The def property of a Panel Ref usually has a value in the format of “x(y)”
A) What information comes before the parenthesis? (What is the x?)
B) What information is defined within the parenthesis? (What is the y?)
sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo
Gi

questionData.question: The def property of a Panel Ref usually has a value in the format of “x(y)”
questionData.answer: A) What information comes before the parenthesis? (What is the x?) B) What information is defined within the parenthesis? (What is the y?) The correct responses are: A) The xis the name of the container to reference. B) The y is a list of objects to pass to the child container to use as root objects. sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
7 ~~ The def property of a Panel Ref usually has a value in the format of “x(y)”
•
A) What information comes before the parenthesis? (What is the x?)
B) What information is defined within the parenthesis? (What is the y?)
The correct responses are:
A) The xis the name of the container to reference.
B) The y is a list of objects to pass to the child container to use as root objects.
sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
AScreen with Card references a Detail View. The Detail View contains a
x Text Input widget. To allow the user to edit the text input value, what must
be set to editable?
sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo
Gi

questionData.question: AScreen with Card references a Detail View. The Detail View contains a
questionData.answer: X Text Input widget. To allow the user to edit the text input value, what must : be set to editable? The Input Widget and all of the containers that directly or indirectly contain it must be set to editable. The editable hierarchy begins with a location PCF Element. Assuming that the Screen declared in a Page location, then the Page location must be set to editable. sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer Gi
AScreen with Card references a Detail View. The Detail View contains a
x Text Input widget. To allow the user to edit the text input value, what must
be set to editable?
The Input Widget and all of the containers that directly or indirectly contain it must be
set to editable. The editable hierarchy begins with a location PCF Element. Assuming
that the Screen declared in a Page location, then the Page location must be set to
editable.
sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
In Studio, can you add Edit Buttons directly to:
A) Aninline Detail View widget?
B) A Detail View PCF file?
sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo

questionData.question: In Studio, can you add Edit Buttons directly to:
questionData.answer: In Studio, can you add Edit Buttons directly to: sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe An inline Detail View widget? A Detail View PCF file? Correct responses are: No, you cannot add Edit Buttons directly to a Detail View widget. Typically, you add a Toolbar to a Screen. Then you add Edit Buttons to the Toolbar. A Detail View widget can be declared on a Screen. No, you cannot add Edit Buttons directly to a Detail View PCF file. Typically, you add a Toolbar to a Screen. Then you add Edit Buttons to the Toolbar. A Panel Ref can reference the Detail View PCF file.

•

Where do you typically add a toolbar with edit buttons?
You add a toolbar with edit buttons typically to the Screen container element.
